entries.name: Loud
entries: Attacks with this weapon emit a piercing crack, audible out to 300 feet.

entries.name: Kick
entries: This weapon can be used with one or two hands. You have disadvantage on ranged attack rolls with it using one hand, unless your Strength score is equal to or higher than the weapon's kick score.

entries.name: Pocket
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity(Sleight of Hand) check to conceal this weapon.

entries.name: Reload
entries: This weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its reload score before it must be reloaded before it can be fired again. Reloading takes an action or bonus action. You must have a free hand to reload.

entries.name: Ammunition
entries: You can discharge a firearm only if appropriate ammunition has been loaded into the weapon. Each time you discharge a firearm, you expend one piece of ammunition. Firearm ammunition is destroyed on use.

entries.name: Shotguns
entries: The damage of a shotgun increases to 1d12 when attacking a target within 10 feet of you.

item.name: Ace Of Spaces
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

{@optfeature firefly|HA:GS|{@b Firefly.}} When you kill a hostile creature with a critical hit using this weapon, the target explodes in a sudden conflagration, as if a fireball spell were cast centered on it.
{@i Inscription: Read 'em and weep}

item.name: Lawgiver
item.reqAttune: by a creature of lawful alignment
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

{@optfeature death sentence|HA:GS|{@b Death Sentence.}} If a creature that isn't attuned to this weapon attempts to make an attack with it, the weapon casts the disintegrate spell on that creature before the attack is made.

item.name: Little Rascal
entries: {@optfeature underdog|HA:GS|{@b Underdog.}} When you hit a Large or larger creature with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 damage of the weapon's type.

item.name: Rounds
entries: Used with Pistols & Rifles

item.name: Shotshells
entries: Used with Shotguns

item.name: Heat Seekers
entries: Used with All firearms. When you attack a creature that isn't a Construct or an Undead using this ammunition, you gain a +1 bonus to the attack roll, and the target gains no benefit from cover for the attack.

item.name: Incendiary
entries: Used with All firearms. Attacks using this ammunition that hit deal fire damage instead of the weapon's normal damage type, cause the target to start burning (1d6), and ignite flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried.

item.name: Silvered
entries: Used with All firearms.

items: A burning creature takes fire damage at the start of each of its turns. This damage is shown in the triggering effect in parentheses.
The creature sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet.

If a creature is subjected to burning from multiple sources, only the highest source of damage applies; they aren't added together. For example, a creature subjected to burning (1d6) and burning (2d6) takes 2d6 fire damage at the start of each of its turns.
The condition ends if the creature or another creature within reach of it uses an action to put out the flames, or some other effect douses it, such as being submerged in water.

tools: Thieves' tools, tinker's tools, or one type of gaming set

default: a {@item leather armor|phb} and a {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) a {@item Pistol, hand cannon|HA:GS} and 20 {@item Rounds|HA:GS} or (b) a repeating rifle and 20 {@item Rounds|HA:GS} or (c) a sawed-off shotgun and 20 {@item Shotshells|HA:GS}
(a) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb} or (b) an {@item explorer's pack|phb}

fluff.name: Gunslinger
entries: An old saloon, scored with bullets and stained with blood, stands before a lone gunslinger. "Ike Williams, I've come for you!" she yells, cutting through the revelry within. As silence descends, she waits, the wind grasping at her scarf and spitting dust across her path. A hulking man pushes through the doors. "Heh," he sneers, fingering a gun at his hip. "And what's a little—" he begins, moving to draw, but she is faster, her fists full of roaring thunder.

In the hostelry's basement, an old man heaves himself from a copper bathtub, steam clinging to his scarred body. "Evil comes," he whispers in a cracked voice. The exclamations of his bathing companions are cut short by the sound of heavy, dragging footfalls overhead. The man mutters a brief prayer as he recovers his gun belt from a loose pile of clothes.

A mercenary gauges his final opponent through a haze of smoke. She returns his appraising stare from over her cards. She waits, biting on her cigar before throwing in a stack of chips, but her nervous chewing betrays the bluff. The man returns her smile. "All in."

With an aim as sharp as their wit, gunslingers pursue their own ends for their own reasons, beholden to no code except their own, and trusting no judgment save that learned through experience. The wild frontier breeds hard folk to hard ways, a dangerous land where life can hinge on a deal of the cards or the speed of the draw.

entries.name: Creating a Gunslinger
entries: When building a gunslinger, consider how you came to live by the gun. Was it for justice? Fame? To protect someone or something you hold dear? And what drives you now? The reassuring clink of coin in your pocket? The righteous satisfaction of vanquishing evil? Maybe past transgressions weigh heavy on your heart, driving you to find redemption? Or do you seek revenge? Who is the character behind the gun?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a gunslinger by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score followed by Wisdom. Second, choose {@background criminal} or {@background folk hero} background.

classFeature.name: Deadeye
entries: Starting at 1st level, In combat, you find your flow with deadly efficiency. Whenever you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack, the lowest number you must roll on the d20 to score a critical hit with subsequent ranged weapon attacks decreases by one. You can gain this benefit multiple times, but it can't 4reduce the threshold for scoring a critical hit below 16.
You lose this benefit if you miss with an attack, you become incapacitated, or if your turn ends and you haven't attacked a creature since your last turn.
From 14th level, whenever you gain this benefit you can gain it one additional time, but it still can't reduce the threshold for scoring a crit hit below 16

classFeature.name: Bad Medicine
entries: Starting at 1st level, You can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a firearm. The number of additional dice increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Bad Medicine column of the Gunslinger table.

classFeature.name: Grit
entries: Starting at 2nd level, The hard-fought battles of your past have instilled in you a wellspring of resolve, which is represented by grit points. You have a number of grit points equal to 1 + your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1 point).

You can spend these points to fuel various grit features. You start knowing four such features: Buck Up, Bullet Time, Covering Fire, and Dodge Roll. You learn more grit features as you gain levels in this class.

When you spend a grit point, it is unavailable until you regain it. You regain 1 expended grit point whenever you score a critical hit against a hostile creature, and you regain all expended grit points when you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Buck Up
entries: You can spend 1 grit point as a bonus action to spend one or more Hit Dice, following the normal rules for regaining hit points using Hit Dice. The maximum number of HitDice you can spend each time you use this feature equals your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Bullet Time
entries: When a creature you can see makes a ranged attack against you, you can spend 1 grit point to impose disadvantage on the attack roll.

entries.name: Covering Fire
entries: While you are holding a firearm, when a creature you can see within 60 feet of you makes an attack against a creature other than you, you can spend 1 grit point as a reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll.

entries.name: Dodge Roll
entries: You can spend 1 grit point as a bonus action to move up to 10 feet without provoking opportunity attacks. You can't take this bonus action if your speed is 0.

classFeature.name: Quickdraw
entries: Starting at 2nd level, You have advantage on initiative rolls. In addition, whenever you draw or stow a firearm, you can draw or stow any number of weapons as part of the same move or action.

classFeature.name: Gunslinger Trail
entries: Starting at 3rd level, You choose a path to walk: Maverick, Beastrider, Enforcer, Preacher, or Revelator, each of which is detailed at the end of the class's description. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Lock N' Load
entries: Starting at 5th level, You can load or reload a firearm you are holding as part of your move or your action.

classFeature.name: Gunslinger Trail feature
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain one feature granted by your Gunslinger Trail.

classFeature.name: Ace In The Hole
entries: Starting at level 7th, Once per turn when you miss with an attack roll, you can spend 1 grit point to add your Wisdom modifier to the roll, potentially turning the miss into a hit.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Born Lucky
entries: Starting at 9th level, When you are forced to make a saving throw, you can spend 1 grit point to make it with advantage.

classFeature.name: Gunslinger Trail feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger Trail.

classFeature.name: Frontier Justice
entries: Starting at 11th level, When a creature you can see willingly moves into a space within 10 feet of you while you are wielding a firearm, you can use your reaction to make one ranged weapon attack against that creature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Skullcracker
entries: Starting at 13th level, When you deal damage with a ranged weapon attack to a creature that is concentrating, the target has disadvantage on the saving throw it makes to maintain its concentration. If the attack is a critical hit, the target automatically fails this saving throw.

classFeature.name: Deadeye Improvement
entries: Starting at 14th level, In combat, you find your flow with deadly efficiency. Whenever you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack, the lowest number you must roll on the d20 to score a critical hit with subsequent ranged weapon attacks decreases by one. You can gain this benefit multiple times, but it can't 4reduce the threshold for scoring a critical hit below 16.
You lose this benefit if you miss with an attack, you become incapacitated, or if your turn ends and you haven't attacked a creature since your last turn.
From 14th level, whenever you gain this benefit you can gain it one additional time, but it still can't reduce the threshold for scoring a crit hit below 16

classFeature.name: Cheat Death
entries: Starting at 15th level, When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can spend 1 grit point to drop to 1 hit point instead. Each time you do so, you gain 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: Starting at 16th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Gunslinger Trail feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger Trail.

classFeature.name: True Grit
entries: Starting at 18th level, When you start your turn and have no grit points remaining, you regain 1 grit point.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Golden Gun
entries: Starting at 20th level, You have advantage on ranged weapon attack rolls while the threshold for scoring a critical hit is 16 or lower

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level feature (enhances Ability Score Improvement)}

When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill proficiency offered by your class at 1st level (the proficiency you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: {@i 8th-level feature (enhances Ability Score Improvement)}

When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill proficiency offered by your class at 1st level (the proficiency you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: {@i 12th-level feature (enhances Ability Score Improvement)}

When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill proficiency offered by your class at 1st level (the proficiency you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: {@i 16th-level feature (enhances Ability Score Improvement)}

When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill proficiency offered by your class at 1st level (the proficiency you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: {@i 19th-level feature (enhances Ability Score Improvement)}

When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill proficiency offered by your class at 1st level (the proficiency you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

subclassFeature.name: Maverick

entries: I tried being reasonable—I didn't like it.

Rulebreakers, groundbreakers, and, often, heartbreakers, mavericks are those loose cannons who dance on a razor's edge and live life like there's no tomorrow. Armed with a quick wit and quicker trigger, they're out to make a name for themselves no matter the cost—and to the Hells with anyone, or anything, that stands in their way.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Card
entries: Starting at 3rd level, Your inscrutable manner veils your intentions. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation} skill. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill or one skill of your choice from the gunslinger skill list. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make against an intelligent creature that uses {@skill Intimidation} while you are carrying a weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Snapshot
entries: Also at 3rd level, When you roll initiative, you can spend 1 grit point as a reaction to draw a firearm and make one ranged attack with it against a creature or object you can see.

subclassFeature.name: Rough And Tumble
entries: Starting at 6th level, You can use a bonus action to {@action dash}, and throw an object you are holding against at a creature within 5 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Dexterity modifier) or be blinded until the end of your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Notorious
entries: Starting at 10th level, Dramatic tales of your virtue or villainy have traveled far enough to establish a well-known alias. Whenever you make a Charisma check against a creature that is aware of your alias, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

subclassFeature.name: High Noon
entries: Starting at 17th level, You can target up to six creatures or objects you can see with your Snapshot, making a separate attack roll for each.

subclassFeature.name: Beastrider

entries: If a dog is man's best friend, then a gun and a horse are his most loyal servants

A beastrider is born to the saddle, capable of taming any beast and riding any mount. While any fool can jump on an old mare, it takes more than reins and spurs to master a spirited beast. Living life fast, both literally and figuratively, the beastrider knows freedom tastes better at a gallop, and a loyal companion is worth more than gold.

subclassFeature.name: To The Manor Born
entries: Starting at 3rd level, Whether through hard work or natural talent, you possess a level and breadth of skill few can match. You gain proficiency in two skills of your choice from the gunslinger skill list, one of which should be {@skill Animal Handling} if you aren't already proficient in it.
In addition, choose one of your skill proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses the chosen skill.

subclassFeature.name: Broncbuster
entries: Also at 3rd level, As an action, you can touch a Beast that is at least one size larger than you and that has an appropriate anatomy to serve as a mount. It must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier) or become charmed by you until you dismiss it, you use this feature to charm a different creature, or you die. While charmed in this way, the target is friendly to you and acts under your control while you are riding it. A creature that successfully saves against this effect is immune to it for 24 hours, after which time it can be affected again. A creature you are fighting automatically succeeds on the saving throw.

Your gunslinger level determines the range of beasts you can charm in this way, as shown in the Mounts table. At 3rd level, for example, you can attempt to charm any Beast that has a challenge rating of 1/2 or lower that doesn't have a flying or swimming speed:
In addition, while you are mounted and aren't incapacitated, your mount gains a bonus to its AC and saving throws equal to your proficiency bonus while it isn't wearing barding or other armor.

subclassFeature.name: Rough Rider
entries: Starting at 6th level, Whenever you take the {@action Attack} action, you can forgo one of the attacks from that action to command a mount you are controlling to use its action to make one weapon attack, choosing from those in its stat block.

subclassFeature.name: Rider's Reflexes
entries: Also at 6th level, When a creature you can see hits your mount with an {@action attack}, you can spend 1 grit point as a reaction to halve the attack's damage against it.

subclassFeature.name: Blazing Saddles
entries: Starting at 10th level, While you are mounted and aren't incapacitated, your mount ignores difficult terrain. Furthermore, whenever your mount takes the {@action Dash} action, it gains additional movement equal to your walking speed.

subclassFeature.name: Air Superiority
entries: Starting at 17th level, Bestride your mount, you soar, you are the eagle. When you use your Covering Fire while flying, you can make one ranged weapon attack against the attacking creature as part of the same reaction, provided the target is within your weapon's range.

subclassFeature.name: Enforcer

entries: Do I get my money now or after I've killed you?

Even in bad company, enforcers have a reputation for giving as good as they get, shrugging off blow after blow and returning tenfold. Yet it is not only their tenacity that makes them a valuable ally but also their keen insight; a knack for sniffing out the truth that is as dangerous to an adversary as any arms they bring to bear.

subclassFeature.name: Bloodhound
entries: Starting at 3rd level, You learn the telltale signs of dishonesty and evasiveness. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Insight} skill. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency in another skill of your choice from the gunslinger skill list. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make to determine the motive or intent of a Humanoid that uses {@skill Insight}.

subclassFeature.name: Rugged Endurance
entries: At 3rd level, You know how to roll with the punches, so to speak. Whenever you regain hit points during combat, you gain the same number of temporary hit points. These temporary hit points last until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Unforgiven
entries: Also at 3rd level, If your first {@action attack} on your turn hits a creature that attacked you or targeted you with a spell or other harmful effect since the end of your last turn, you can roll one additional weapon damage die and add it to the damage of your {@action attack}.

subclassFeature.name: Sharp Eye
entries: Starting at 6th level, Experience and necessity have honed your ability to discern your surroundings at a glance. You can take the {@action Search} action as a bonus action on your turn.
In addition, while you are resting, or you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.

subclassFeature.name: Hard Case
entries: Starting at 10th level, While you have temporary hit points, you can't be charmed or frightened. Furthermore, when you use your Buck Up, you can make a saving throw to end one effect on yourself that is causing you to be charmed or frightened.

subclassFeature.name: King Of The Hill
entries: Starting at 17th level, Once per turn, you can spend 1 grit point to use your Frontier Justice feature without using your reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Preacher

entries: Why, you look like someone just walked over your grave.

Whatever the raiment, symbols, and ceremonies of their faith, firearms are but divine implements in the preacher's holy arsenal. Faith is their greatest weapon, devotion their greatest strength. As enigmatic as the gods they serve, the preacher gives life with one hand and takes it away with the other.
At your option, you can use the Motivations table to help discover the reason for your character choosing to follow the preacher's path:

entries.caption: Motivations
rows: You're following in the footsteps of a guardian or mentor.
You made a promise to someone you hold dear.
You seek atonement for a life of drinking and wickedness.

subclassFeature.name: Man of the Cloth
entries: Starting at 3rd level, You have proven yourself worthy to take your god's holy vows. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Religion} skill. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency in one skill of your choice from the gunslinger skill list.
In addition, you learn two cantrips of your choice from the cleric spell list. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

subclassFeature.name: Sacrifice
entries: Also at 3rd level, Through the ardency of your faith, you can heal others at a cost to yourself. When you use your Buck Up, you can choose another creature within 60 feet of you that you can see to regain hit points instead of you. For each Hit Die spent, roll the die and add your Wisdom modifier to it. The target regains hit points equal to the total (minimum of 1 hit point). This feature has no effect on Constructs or Undead.

subclassFeature.name: Strength of Spirit
entries: Starting at 6th level, Your unwavering resolve is a balm to your spirit. At the end of a long rest, you regain all spent Hit Dice, instead of up to half your total number of them.

subclassFeature.name: Cleanse
entries: Starting at 10th level, Whenever you restore hit points to a creature using your Buck Up or your Sacrifice, it also ends the blinded, deafened, and poisoned conditions on the target, and cures any diseases or poisons affecting it.

subclassFeature.name: Revitalize
entries: Starting at 17th level, You can target a creature that has been dead for no longer than one minute with your Sacrifice. When you do so, the target returns to life if its soul is free and willing, regaining hit points from Sacrifice normally. This ability can't restore to life a creature that has died of old age or is a Construct or an Undead, nor can it restore any missing body parts. A creature can be returned to life in this way no more than once between long rests.

subclassFeature.name: Revelator

entries: Sometimes it takes a devil to kill a devil.

The revelator is the shield of the innocent and the sword of the just, seeking to uphold the law and punish the wicked. While some join organizations dedicated to eradicating evil, earning a rank and title from their order, others work alone, waging a more personal war, seeking to avenge a great wrong or defeat a terrible evil. No matter the method, no matter the reason, all are driven to a righteous cause. Where injustice persists, where iniquity dwells, the revelator comes.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Righteous
entries: Starting at 3rd level, You arm yourself with knowledge of evil and its crooked ways. You gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}, or {@skill Religion}. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Intelligence check you make to recall information about fiends or undead.

subclassFeature.name: Consecrate Arms
entries: At 3rd level, As an action, you can touch a willing creature and utter a prayer to sanctify it. Whenever that creature hits with a weapon {@action attack}, the attack deals radiant damage instead of the weapon's normal damage type. This benefit lasts until the creature dismisses it (no action required), the creature dies, or it finishes a short or long rest.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Baptism of Fire
entries: Also at 3rd level, With holy fire you deliver judgment unto your enemies. When you hit a creature with a ranged weapon {@action attack} while benefiting from your Consecrate Arms, you can spend 1 grit point to deal 1d8 radiant damage to the target, in addition to the weapon's damage. The damage increases by 1d8 if the target is a Fiend or an Undead.

subclassFeature.name: Dead Reckoning
entries: Starting at 6th level, You develop a keen instinct for the presence or influence of outsiders and undead. You are always under the effects of a {@spell detect evil and good} spell, and you know when you are in the lair of an Aberration, Celestial, Elemental, Fey, Fiend, or Undead.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Shackles
entries: Starting at 10th level, When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you attempts to travel using teleportation or by extradimensional or interplanar means, you can spend 1 grit point as a {@action reaction} to force that creature to make a Charisma saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier). On a failed save, the attempt at travel fails and is wasted.

subclassFeature.name: Ashes to Ashes
entries: Starting at 17th level, Whenever you hit a Fiend or an Undead with a weapon {@action attack} while benefiting from your Consecrate Arms, the target is instantly destroyed if the attack reduces it to 50 hit points or fewer.

feat.name: Bully

prerequisite.other: Proficiency with at least one firearm

entries: You are adept at using firearms in close quarters, gaining the following benefits:

items: Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls.

Once per turn, when you hit a creature within 10 feet of you with a ranged {@action attack} using a firearm, you can force the target to make a Strength saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Dexterity modifier). On a failed save, you push the target 5 feet away from you and knock it {@condition prone}.

feat.name: Marksman
entries: You are an expert at hitting your mark with ranged weapons, gaining the following benefits:

items: Being prone doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged weapon attacks.
Attacking a prone target doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged weapon attack rolls if the target is within your weapon's normal range.

If you haven't moved since the start of your turn, you can use a bonus action to steady your aim. Until the end of your next turn, you have advantage on the next ranged weapon attack roll you make. This effect ends early if you move or take damage.

feat.name: Pistolero
entries: Your speed and skill with a six-gun is unmatched. You gain the following benefits:

items: When you take the Attack action and attack with a one-handed weapon, you can use a bonus action to attack with a pistol you are holding in your other hand.
If you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren't incapacitated, you can act normally on your first turn, but only if you attack with a pistol before doing anything else on that turn.

intro: The following table presents the average damage of the gunslinger based on a Monte Carlo method simulating 100,000 rounds of attacks at each level against a Normal Distribution of Armor Class values appropriate for that level. Similar data sets using existing builds are also presented following the same methodology for comparative purposes.

outro: {@b Average Combat Duration:} Combats last three to four rounds, with a slight skew toward three.
{@b Average Number of Encounters:} One or two combat encounters per short rest, with two short rests per long rest.
{@b Feats:} Taken as soon as possible, starting at 4th level.
{@b Enemy Armor Class:} Extrapolated from official guidelines for creating monsters.

{@b Battlemaster:} Only uses the Precision Attack maneuver, and only on attacks that miss by 4 or less. Always take the option on Sharpshooter for every attack roll not made at disadvantage once that option is available.

{@b Maverick:} Three-in-ten chance to use Frontier Justice. On average, three creatures are available as targets for High Noon when rolling initiative (ó = 1). Always uses Ace in the Hole to turn a miss into a hit.
{@b Thief:} One-in-two chance to make the first attack on a turn with advantage. Always uses Stroke of Luck to turn a missed sneak attack into a hit.

variantrule.name: Rules Questions
entries: Answers to common rules questions are presented here.

entries.name: Is this class compatible with official firearms?
entries: This class is compatible with the official firearms should you wish to use them.

entries.name: Does bullet time take a reaction?
entries: No, grit points are the only cost to using Bullet Time.

entries.name: Is there a limit to the number of times I can reload a firearm with Lock n' Load?
entries: No. Reloading effectively becomes "free" with Lock n' Load, but only on your turn, and you must still have a free hand

entries.name: When can I use Frontier Justice?
entries: You can use Frontier Justice to attack a creature that is advancing on you, retreating from you, or moving past you.

entries.name: Can I use snapshot if I'm surprised?
entries: No, a surprised creature can't take a reaction until the end of its first turn in a combat.

entries.name: Can I pick up an object as part of the bonus action to use Rough and Tumble?
entries: No. However, you can interact with one object or feature of the environment for free on your turn.

entries.name: Does unforgiven stack?
entries: No, only one instance of the bonus granted by Unforgiven can be added to the damage of your attack. This follows the general rules for combining game effects.

entries.name: Can I swap between ammunition types?
entries: Changing the ammunition loaded in a firearm is considered the same interaction as reloading it.

variantrule.name: META Questions
entries: Design commentary cleverly disguised as questions.

entries.name: My GM doesn't like guns / gunslingers
entries: If you dig the mechanics but don't like guns or gunslingers, you can reflavor the gunslinger as an arbalist or a spellless ranger with some creative license and the following mechanical changes:

items: Replace any instances of "firearm" with "bow or crossbow", "pistol" with "hand crossbow", and "rifle" and "shotgun" with "heavy crossbow".

entries.name: Why a new class?
entries: We believe this class offers a more unique, exciting, and genuine expression of the fantasy (or fiction) of firearms than could be reasonably achieved in a smaller package.

entries.name: Is there a limit to the number of times I can reload a firearm with Lock n' Load?
entries: No. Reloading effectively becomes "free" with Lock n' Load, but only on your turn, and you must still have a free hand

entries.name: Why new firearms?
entries: We believe the firearms presented herein are more representative of the desired aesthetic, as well as being more varied and interesting than official options.

entries.name: Can I allow multiclassing?
entries: Yes, multiclassing with the gunslinger won't cause anyone any headaches. We promise.

entries.name: and feats?
entries: There are no problematic feats for the gunslinger. In fact, this class suffers less from heavy optimization than many others because Deadeye and the Sharpshooter feat are dissonant. Here's a quick rundown of some options you might consider for your gunslinger character:

items: {@b New Feats.} Each of these is a strong and flavorful option suited to different builds and playstyles.
{@b Elven Accuracy.} Excellent synergy with the Marksman feat and other effects that provide a consistent source of advantage, such as Golden Gun.
{@b Fighting Initiate (Archery).} Almost as strong as the new feats (but not quite, and nowhere near as fun!)
{@b Sharpshooter.} Conflicts with Deadeye, as noted above. You can still use it effectively, though it can be challenging to do so without a consistent source of advantage.

entries.name: Using Alternate Ability Scores
entries: Wisdom was deemed the most appropriate mental ability score for representing an archetypal gunslinger. However, should you wish to play as a character with the presence of Clint Eastwood or intellect of Doc Holliday, ask your GM if you can substitute your Wisdom modifier for your Charisma or Intelligence modifier in any gunslinger features that reference it.

entries.name: A Last Request
entries: If you came by this document for free, then its probably stolen. That's okay! We'd rather people enjoy our content than not. However, a great deal of effort and expense went into creating this product, so please consider supporting it with a purchase if you have the means to do so. Thank you!
